children.subject: just wondering, are you a rising sophomore/junior/senior? I am pretty much in the same situation with an 8-hour TA offer and more classes (rising sophomore).

I wholly agree with this -- as someone who's done this before, it's possible but at least for me, wasn't very healthy. I never cut into sleep but I cut into self-care/workout time, and as a result looked and felt a lot worse by the end of the semester. Maybe you have better time management than me, but I'd really like to echo that you should only do something like this if it's something you really care about.

Is it possible? Yes, I've done something similar fall semester of my senior year (two research opportunities with different profs in BAIR, full course load including some math/stat graduate courses, studying for GRE + subject test, applying to grad school). Time commitment is no joke with a load like that; its at the point where you start calculating how to best optimize the amount of sleep you get and then you realize that you can't afford to sleep that much. 

Would I recommend it to anybody? Probably not but if you do want to follow through, make sure that every opportunity is something that you truly want. Your semester's already going to be hard enough, don't make it any harder by choosing a commitment for the wrong reasons.

history.content: The short answer is yes. I am a rising senior who has been working as a 20hr TA for quite a few semesters now in addition to working at a research lab in BAIR and taking 16-19 units/2 techs a semester. You mostly need to have good time management skills - procrastinating isn't going to work too well when you have about as much work as time. You also need to be good at recognizing when you start to feel overwhelmed and communicating these things with your research advisor/course staff team. Trust me, they will understand and work with you to help you out. I also don't consider myself exceptionally smart but that honestly doesn't help too much for most of these things. Working hard will get you most of the way there. But you really have to take a hard look at yourself, your study/work habits, and your goals to know whether you are capable of doing everything and whether it is worth it.

Hi, has anyone done research + TA + classes before and can speak on the time commitment? I will be a 15-hour TA for an upper division CS class in the fall and will also be taking 162 + 16b + breadth. I intend to go to grad school so I hope to gauge whether I have enough time to contribute decently to a research project in BAIR or RISE. I don't consider myself exceptionally smart but I'm willing to put in the work (if it is even doable). Would appreciate if anyone with experience doing this could respond!
history.subject: Time commitment of research + TA + classes?
